text:
Hey everyone, after five years of being in social media marketing for large agencies like Ogilvy and VMLY&R I've decided to try and transition into a more e-commerce/ digital strategy/ growth role. 

Is there anyone here who's a growth hacker/ digital strategist who can give some tips on how I should make that career transition from social media manager?

text:
Is there a reason beside “the cost of living here is cheaper” that pushes you to set “reasonable prices?”

I’m asking because you’re not doing yourself a favor thinking like this. It’s not good for your bank account either. And also, you’re not being helpful to your fellow copywriters from South Africa.

Just look for clients that can pay you what you’re worth and never fix prices based on the fact that you’re living in a cheap place.

text: I hear you and it's definitely not the only reason I'm going freelance but at the same time companies outsourcing to save costs is a reality and something I want to position myself to capitalize on in the short term. Long term though ofcoz it's not a winning strategy, my ultimate goal is to help small businesses with digital marketing

text:
Hi everyone,
I hope everyone is having a fantastic new year!
I’m three years into freelancing. Loving it so far, and the Superpath’s group is amazing! However, I need some help in refining my niche.
So far, I have a background in science. I know about tech, data science, data analytics, and I’m very passionate about the environment.
In the last year, I have worked with B2B SaaS companies in other areas sales, e-commerce, chatbots, and cloud technology.
The work I did was good, and I got some referrals and inbound clients as well. But somehow, I think I wasn’t unable to show my full potential. I want to work in the areas that I know, and I’m passionate about while earning good money. However, I’m not sure what will be my niche and what kind of companies I should focus on.
Any advice is highly appreciated! Thank you!

text:
Hey <@U01J84U3SQ6>!

Since you have worked in these industries, you might know which industry you enjoy workibg for the most. 

Think about this—which is one industry out of this for whom I can endlessly conduct research and not get bored. Double down on those industries and write. You don't have to double down to just one niche, it could be 2-3 industries you like too.

But make sure, you enjoy the entire process while working for these industries only then niching down will be beneficial for you.

All the best:-)

text:
Well first off get specific. If you're going to use up someones time asking for advice give them all of the information they need.
What field are you in, what are your top skills, what role/level are you seeing, is there a geographical constraint.
All in all, get specific- this might be your broader mishap with "getting clients" too

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hi everyone. I'm a freelance SEO content writer, been at this for over a year now. The issue now is that I realized I've been focusing on B2C content, but my heart right now is on B2B content. I've checked out works in that niche and I know I can pull it off plus it will suit my career journey.

So for B2B writers seeing this, freelancing or not, what kind of samples or paid work did you do that helped you get in? Jobs I've been seeing always ask for experience or like 3 B2B writing samples. So I'm confused on the kind of writing piece to create to pitch to clients if I'm not working under a B2B company or an agency.

For marketing execs or those that work with B2B writers, what kind of samples do you look out for? Is there a chance that writers without B2B Samples can be hired with samples from other niches or cos they show enthusiasm and potential in their work?"

Most customers/employers I’ve encountered that request samples look for pieces that are either:
• written about or within their industry
• closely related to the topic they want to cover
• of the style/format they want to pursue
You’ll generally get better results if you have content samples that fit the above. If you don’t have any, you can sometimes get away with providing a sample at a discounted rate so that you can prove you can write to their audience convincingly

elements.text: Most customers/employers I’ve encountered that request samples look for pieces that are either:
written about or within their industry
closely related to the topic they want to cover
of the style/format they want to pursue

You’ll generally get better results if you have content samples that fit the above. If you don’t have any, you can sometimes get away with providing a sample at a discounted rate so that you can prove you can write to their audience convincingly

text: That said, sometimes enthusiasm isn’t enough. industries like cybersecurity and medtech are very hard for outsiders to get into unless they have a LONG list of previous work, simply because the subjects are so niche and technical

elements.text: That said, sometimes enthusiasm isn’t enough. industries like cybersecurity and medtech are very hard for outsiders to get into unless they have a LONG list of previous work, simply because the subjects are so niche and technical

text:
Clients do want to see something that's related to their industry. I'm a freelance writer too who has written for plentiful of industries in the past and later decided to transition to B2B industry. But the only struggle i had was I didn't have a portfolio relevant to the industry. Instead of doing paid work, I focussed on building up my portfolio.

My suggestion to you would be to do some guest blogging work + write on medium. Do this and then pitch to clients you want to work with. 

There are times prospects aren't sure if I'm the right fit so I do a paid test for them. If it's approved, I work with them.

Don't thing you'll be hired without samples. That's a requirement. So double down on 3-5 b2b industries you want to work with and create samples for those industries.

Hope this helps:-)
